body: Still trying to figure out a bug where executables aren't getting the executable bit set...
Seems to have resolved itself with a rebase ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Can you write a run-make test that checks the compiler is correctly searching for, parsing and using external specifications? (E.g. it could run `rustc --target=foo-bar-baz --emit=asm ...` with a custom target that disables stack checks, and then grep for stack checks.)

Another issue: probably needs to allow specifying `target_os` instead of taking it from the target triple. I'm not actually sure this is a good idea, though, and it seems MUCH more clear that the target_os comes from the triple name itself. But we'd need to rename "osx" to "darwin", which I feel is almost a lie? Not really sure. Need feedback.
(The RFC specifies taking it from the target)
@huonw how do those docs look?
Hm, glaringly obvious problem: `linker` should probably include a target triple prefix, for cross compiling. ie, `x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu-cc`.
@farcaller we should try this with `arm-none-eabi`

Be warned that this isn't quite working yet. My current status is:

```
LLVM ERROR: not a number, or does not fit in an unsigned int
```
(Already fixed I think, still building..)

```
ix88::mode_t;

::c_int;

maybe you meant `stat::*`?)

, fstat, mkdir, stat};

                ^~~~
error: aborting due to 115 previous errors

/lib/stamp.libc] Error 101
```

Maybe the `target_os` is incorrectly determined?

The commit message also needs to be improve to adhere to the [breaking changes policy](https://mail.mozilla.org/pipermail/rust-dev/2014-April/009543.html) as it doesn't explain what the breaking change is, why the change is being made, or how to migrate code.

If this renames our windows triples, it doesn't seem to touch the configure script or makefiles, so how is that supposed to work?

```
DEBUG:rustc::middle::dependency_format: adding dylib: rand
```

(with `RUST_LOG=rustc::back=4,rustc_back=4,rustc::middle=4,rustc::middle::typeck=1 make`).

This started happening after a rebase about a week ago.
(Adding tests and fixing build system now...)
Alright, modulo not working, should be good to go.

@alexcrichton as for the JSON decoding, I'd rather just defer that for now. One problem is that either we create two structures, one with `Option` fields for JSON decoding and one without (which has defaults filled in for the rest of the compiler to use), or the rest of the compiler needs to know the defaults for those `Option` fields. The benefit of the former is that it's impossible to leave out fields via destructuring, but I honestly don't see a way to shoehorn leaving out fields into the JSON decoder. It doesn't seem to keep track of names(?) and would need a hefty bit of complexity to skip over absent fields. I'm not sure, though, I couldn't follow the code very well. Perhaps @erickt could chime in.
Hoping this will allow full rustc/cargo building of Zinc (as cargo doesn't support linker args, but this does). hackndev/zinc#130 (https://github.com/bharrisau/zinc/blob/lift/contrib/cortexm4.json)
@bharrisau note that your targets _must_ take the form of `foo-bar-baz`. (I'm fixing that now, for unrelated reasons. I've also fixed the "no_compiler_rt" accident).
I'll have a look after you've updated. I'd normally use `arm-none-eabi` but you are(were) taking the target OS from `pieces[2]` which would be "eabi" instead of the desired "none".
@cmr, is this close to being landed?
rebasing...

This is continuing to look great @cmr, nice job! It would be great if someone could double check to make sure that all the knowledge of `back::link` was transferred to `back::target` correctly, I caught a few things here and there but there may be more lingering.

I also don't think that there has been much discussion about renaming the windows triples, so I'm hesitant to r+ with this a rebase until that has some wider consensus. We'll have to change all of the automation around rustc/cargo as well as the installation scripts once this change lands to update the renaming of the windows triples.
The new windows targets are what LLVM prefers, and that seems as good a precedent as any to me, so +1. Very excited to see what people do with this.
The triple name change will need to be reflected on the wiki and announced somewhere (mailing list I guess).

```
note: having upstream crates all available in one format will likely make this go away

```

which I _haven't_ been able to solve, and it needs a tweak for win64 ABI, which should be simple.
I've only had a chance to [poorly] review the first half. Looking forward to building it and giving it a go with the ARM Cortex stuff in Zinc.
Also - this is some awesome work. Everything looks so much nicer, much less matches in the backend.

Btw, did you try building this on Windows? 
Looks like LLVM's configure doesn't like the new windows triples, ironically:

```
...

configure: error: LLVM configure failed
```

@vadimcn It seems I broke win64 ABI: http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/try-win-64/builds/17/steps/test/logs/stdio

The data layout string hasn't changed, though.

@cmr in `src/librustc/middle/trans/cabi.rs`, `cabi_x86_win64::compute_abi_info` is replaced by `cabi_x86_64::compute_abi_info` but the corresponding `xabi_x86_64::compute_abi_info` has not been updated.
([this part](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/16156#discussion-diff-16323855))
I am going to give it a try also ;)

Just tried to test this with [simias/launchpad-rust](https://github.com/simias/launchpad-rust), although would be great to see some reference on how `"data-layout"` should be defined...

Also, it just crossed my mind, should CPU features be configured through `target.json`, e.g. presence of FPU?

@errordeveloper http://llvm.org/docs/LangRef.html#data-layout has docs for the data layout.

CPU features can be configured in the JSON, by the optional `options` field, in the `features` property.
r? @brson @alexcrichton
